  TITLE: Antioch (Joy to the World) (0:53)
 ARTIST: Isaac Watts (lyrics), Lowell Mason (music)
COMMENT: Mason borrowed two phrases from Händel's Messiah, "Lift Up Your
         Heads," and "Comfort Ye", when writing this melody.

### /MUSICIANS/F\ ############################################################

### /MUSICIANS/G/ ############################################################

### /MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow ####################################################

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/
COMMENT: G-Fellow' (Gerhard Flagge's) own comments are denoted (G-F).
         G-Fellow started composing in 1988 and after a break from
         1991-1998, he did some tunes in 1998 that got released later.
         In 2004 G-Fellow made a comeback in the Commodore 64 scene. His early
         tunes from 1991 and 1998 didn't get released until 2004.

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/A_Bit_Sad.sid
COMMENT: "This is one of my early tunes when I rejoined the C64 scene in 2004."
         (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Appetizer.sid
COMMENT: "Used in a Civitas intro from Chico/Civitas. This tune has some
         oldschool feeling." (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Azax.sid
COMMENT: "This tune has some strange beginning but when you listen longer some
         nice rythm apears. The melody is not so good." (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/C64_Memories_Fades_Away.sid
COMMENT: "Mixed Competition at Willow Party 2004: #10 The party was really
         cool and I try to visit it some year again." (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Call_It_Extasy.sid
COMMENT: "This tune I did 1991 with the Voicetracker. It's a suspending tune.
         I like this old tune." (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Cooler_Cant_Be.sid
COMMENT: "This is one of my favourite tunes that I composed. When I made
         this tune in 1991, I did listen alot to the music group FRONT 242.
         It was inspired by the music group FRONT 242 but it's not a cover."
         (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Cracktro.sid
COMMENT: "This is a intro tune that I composed, it's really short, but I
         think it has something special." (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Crystal.sid
COMMENT: "This tune did I compose also 1991, was first released in 2004 in
         a Civitas Intro. Backdays around 1991 I was not so good with
         melodys." (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Dalezy.sid
COMMENT: "This tune is a tribute for the scener Dalezy, the idea was not to
         cover his style of composing, the tribute is simply that I gave
         the tune his nick name." (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Dark_Edge.sid
COMMENT: "I did this tune for the GameOver(view) mag, this tune is dark and
         sad. I like this tune." (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Destination_X.sid
COMMENT: "This tune was made for the X-2004 party, it made the place #19
         The tune has a intro of 1:07 minutes. I worked two weeks on the
         tune, I like this tune and the crowd aplaud at the party. I think
         the tune is underrated, when I listen to the 4-5 places before
         me than can I not understand that it's only at rank #19." (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Draxme.sid
COMMENT: "Nice and slow tune. I like the melody that I did and the lead voice
         has a good sound." (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Electric_City.sid
COMMENT: "This tune was made for the GameOver(view). This is one of my
         experimentel tunes, that has his own special touch. It's some
         kind of art-tune." (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Firewall.sid
COMMENT: "Not a special tune. It's not one of my favourites." (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Friendly_Energy.sid
COMMENT: "The tune has a long intro, I did the tune 1998 for my own pleasure
         after I found my C64 in some rotten place. ;-) It's a long tune
         and not bad I think, it has some nice sound effekts. I did this
         tune with the Soundbooster v1.0 from Midas. Later it was released
         in the note of MSX-Front 64 #2." (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Funky_Tune.sid
COMMENT: "Again a tune from 1991 that got released in 2004. It's one of my
         bad tunes, I don't like it that much." (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Funstar.sid
COMMENT: "This is one of my favourite tunes that I did after my comeback
         in 2004. It has some kind of DRAX style in it." (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Game_Over_view_7.sid
COMMENT: "A very very sad tune. I did this tune 1991. I don't remember
         the original name of the tune. But it got never released before
         GameOver(view) #7." (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Go_for_It.sid
COMMENT: "A tune made for the C64 Music Competition at tUM 2004. I got the
         place #6 in the compo." (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Goldhawk_4.sid
  TITLE: Goldhawk
 ARTIST: Klaus Engell Grøngaard (Link)
COMMENT: G-Fellow took the ~20 seconds long worktune and added his own stuff to
         it, with permission from Vibrants.

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Grid_Zone.sid
COMMENT: "Richard Bayliss did a game called Grid Zone. He asked me if I can do
         some tunes for the game. But he don't liked the tunes, so he used some
         own tunes. He sayd the tunes are to 'dark'. I think the tunes also not
         that good..." (G-F)

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Independent_God.sid
COMMENT: Made in 1991, released in 2006.

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Jamming_from_the_Past.sid
  TITLE: Discooo
 ARTIST: Thomas Mogensen (DRAX)
COMMENT: G-Fellow took the worktune and added his own stuff to it, with
         permission from DRAX.

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/TTMHBSOTK.sid
   NAME: This Tune Made Himself by Stomping on the Keyboard

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Thinking.sid
COMMENT: Made in 1999, released in 2004.

/MUSICIANS/G/G-Fellow/Wonderfull_Live.sid
COMMENT: Made in 1991, released in 2003.

### /MUSICIANS/G/Galancy/ ####################################################

/MUSICIANS/G/Galancy/
COMMENT: All comments by Jari Ukkola are denoted by (JU).
         "Every tune was composed using Commodore 64 C-type with MOS-8580
         SID-chip. Because of this some tunes might sound strange emulating
         the older and better MOS-6581 SID-chip. This happens specially with
         the tunes with a strong filter effect." (JU)

/MUSICIANS/G/Galancy/Galancy_ATL_009.sid
COMMENT: "Also known as Immortal_Flash_15.sid which has a slightly longer intro
         made by Dr.Science of Atlantis." (JU)

### /MUSICIANS/G/Galancy/Early_Works #########################################

/MUSICIANS/G/Galancy/Early_Works/Fadwell_05.sid
COMMENT: "Also known as Immortal_Flash_11.sid" (JU)

  TITLE: Rent [from Actually]
 ARTIST: Pet Shop Boys

### /MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin ###############################################

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/
COMMENT: Martin Galway's own comments are denoted (MG).
         "I will never do rearrangements of those tunes on other instruments,
         the SID is what they're meant to be heard on. It would not be
         'updating' them to put them onto a different instrument. If you ever
         hear music from me on today's instruments, the tunes will be all-new
         (and probably a lot better)." (MG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Arkanoid.sid
COMMENT: This is the very first published tune on the C64 that used samples.
         "Q: How did you get involved with using sampled sounds?
         MG: I figured out how samples were played by hacking into someone
         else's code... OK, I admit it... It was a drum synthesizer package
         called Digidrums, actually, so you could still say I was the first to
         include samples in a piece of music. [...] Never would I claim to have
         invented that technique, I just got it published first. In fact, I
         couldn't really figure out where they got the sample data, just that
         they were wiggling the volume register, so I tried to make up my own
         drum sample sounds in realtime - which is the flatulence stuff that
         shipped in 'Arkanoid'. [...] After the project was in the shops I
         gained access to some real drum samples, and I slid those into my own
         custom version of the tune. The one that's in the shops is kind of a
         collage of farts & burps, don't you think? [...] Later I was able to
         acquire some proper drum samples and by 'Game Over' it got quite
         sophisticated." (MG)
(#1)
  TITLE: Cobra (Title) [from the Spectrum game]
 ARTIST: Martin Galway
COMMENT: "I'm glad you spotted 'Cobra' on the Spectrum, whose tune I was in
         love with and HAD to use somewhere else...! I figured no-one would
         complain if I used it a year later [for Arkanoid] on the C64." (MG)
(#2)
  TITLE: Hiscore [from the arcade game Arkanoid - Revenge of Doh]
 ARTIST: Hisayoshi Ogura (OGR/Zuntata)
(#3)
  TITLE: Intro [from the arcade game Arkanoid - Revenge of Doh]
 ARTIST: Hisayoshi Ogura (OGR/Zuntata)

         contains the title tune and end-game tune with enhanced drums.

COMMENT: The one that drove Galway insane was "'Athena', because after some
         years of increasing sound quality in the music, I finally had to come
         down... I only had 4K in which to fit the code and music." (MG)
         Tunes 2-6 and 9 appear to be covers of the arcade original.

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Comic_Bakery.sid
(#1)
COMMENT: Tune #1 was also in the game "Top Gun".
         "The only thing I have to say about it is that the title tune started
         off as a cover of 'Hot Water' by Level 42 (oh yeah add them to my
         favourite music list). It went badly awry by the end of the 1st 10
         seconds though and I decided to change it to something else!" (MG)
(#6)
  TITLE: Tea for Two [from the musical No, No, Nanette]
 ARTIST: Irving Caesar (lyrics), Vincent Youmans (music)
COMMENT: First appeared in the 1924 musical 'No, No, Nanette', later featured
         in the 1950 movie 'Tea for Two'.

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Commando_High-Score.sid
  TITLE: Commando, Tune #2
 ARTIST: Rob Hubbard
COMMENT: "I did ONE demo though, it was a version of Rob Hubbard's COMMANDO
         music (the high-score tune), of which I put the only copy on a floppy
         disc and sent it to my biggest fan at the time, Barry Leitch (who is
         now a successful composer in the industry, by the way). Barry lost
         the disc!" (MG)
         The tune is eventually found in a demo by the Anti MSX Group from 1986
         which is called 'AMG Sampler 1'.

         and possibly tune #10.
         "Most of the arcade games we worked on has simpler sound chips than
         the C64's, so I was able to 'beef up the music'". (MG)

         he is the least happy with this music amongst all of his tunes.

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Helikopter_Jagd.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: Ivory Tower [from the movie The NeverEnding Story]
 ARTIST: Giorgio Moroder
COMMENT: "I was still freelancing when I worked on that music first in 1984,
         and I just said to Tony Pomfret 'what do you want for the music?' to
         which he replied 'I want the B-side from the Limahl single
         "Neverending Story" I bought the other day.' At no time were we
         thinking Ocean would publish a "Neverending Story" game, it was very
         much just a cool tune to do. (It was a Georgio Moroder filler tune,
         whose style I had a lot of respect for as a producer). It was the
         first tune I did pulse-width sweeps on, but didn't get released 'til
         after a bunch of other games had come out I think. The sound blew
         everyone away." (MG)
(#3)
  TITLE: Ocean Loader 2
 ARTIST: Martin Galway
COMMENT: This short jingle is an extract of Ocean Loader 2 at about 0:17-0:26.
(#4)
COMMENT: Same as tune #1 with only one audible voice.

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Highlander.sid
  TITLE: A Kind of Magic [from A Kind of Magic]
 ARTIST: Queen
COMMENT: According to Galway, it took him two days to do this tune.

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Hunchback_II.sid
COMMENT: "Bill [Barna] & Tony [Pomfret] convinced me to stay up overnight with
         them finishing 'Hunchback 2' on a cold night in November 1984 so they
         could get their bonuses! (I didn't get a cut of those bonuses
         though... HEY!) I had never been up overnight before and it was a new
         experience, especially since I had to get to college the following
         day..." (MG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Hyper_Sports.sid
COMMENT: Tunes #1 to #24 and #26 are covers of the arcade version.
(#25)
COMMENT: Same as /MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Rolands_Ratrace.sid, Tune #3.
(#26)
  TITLE: Titles [from the movie Chariots of Fire]
 ARTIST: Vangelis

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Insects_in_Space.sid
COMMENT: "I am sorry to see that most composers these days don't have access to
         the kind of tricks I was able to do (being a programmer), which for
         example allowed me to create the 'buzzing bees' effect at the
         beginning of the tune. Too bad, eh?"
         "Well by the time I got to that game (1988) I was a bit hard up for
         ideas. I didn't know what to do with so few notes available! I wanted
         my tunes to build up into much larger entities but I always hit this
         limit. Plus the time at which that game was developed was a pretty
         rough time for Sensi, none of us were too happy at the time. Insects
         In Space was a victim of this. True though, it certainly has
         'character', but it just doesn't go on LONG enough, don't you agree?"
         (MG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Match_Day.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: Offside [from the TV programme Match of the Day]
 ARTIST: Barry Stoller
COMMENT: The title music from the British BBC TV football programme, "Match of
         the Day".

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Miami_Vice.sid
COMMENT: "The Miami Vice game was a very quick job. I had been handed 'Miami
         Vice' and 'Highlander' because the outside development team working on
         it hadn't worked out who was going to do the sound (notice those games
         have little or no sound-effects), so I did my best in a very short
         time. I [...] picked 'The Chase' and the 'Main Theme' as the two tunes
         I would do. We had settled on two modes for the game - in your car and
         out of it I think. (Or maybe it was in the game and out of it, I can't
         remember.) I started on 'The Chase' and if you listen to the first few
         seconds of that you can hear the basis of that super-filter-echo tune
         that is so cool. I recall David Collier was sitting in the office with
         me while I was working on it. But while messing with it while everyone
         else was at lunch, I came across this cool sound. I added to it and
         added to it, and when we applied the non-sync'd filter sweep we both
         flipped out! I decided to abandon the conversion of that tune and
         simply go with the cool sounds I had stumbled upon. When the guys came
         back from lunch and listened to it they swore that there was a
         cassette deck connected somewhere and it wasn't the C64 playing it!
         Such a sound had not been heard before by any of us out of the C64. So
         I extended it and turned it into this tripping-out 11-minute piece.
         The main theme itself... I simply did my best with no drums (Rob
         Hubbard's strength). I think my strength with guitar solos helped pull
         it off. Both of those problematic games benefited from my music,
         actually, and the Ocean management were very relieved
         (understatement)." (MG)
(#1)
  TITLE: Evan (Instrumental) [from the TV series Miami Vice]
 ARTIST: Jan Hammer
COMMENT: Martin did an over-extended remix.
(#2)
  TITLE: Miami Vice Theme [from the TV series]
 ARTIST: Jan Hammer

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/MicroProse_Soccer_outdoor.sid
COMMENT: "Well, a tune could only be hard to compose if I was hard-up for ideas
         at the time - if it was a conversion/arrangement of someone else's
         music it wouldn't be composition, right? 'Microprose Soccer' and
         'Insects In Space' were the toughest, by that definition." (MG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Mikie.sid

  TITLE: A Hard Day's Night [from the movie]
 ARTIST: The Beatles

 ARTIST: Phil Medley & Bert Russell

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Neverending_Story.sid
  TITLE: NeverEnding Story [from the movie The NeverEnding Story]
 ARTIST: Giorgio Moroder, performed by Limahl

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Ocean_Loader_1.sid
COMMENT: "The 'version 1' is a real tune, it was really like that on
         Hypersports and maybe one or two other games before Comic Bakery
         (Cyclone would have used it, for example, but it was never released by
         Ocean). The delay at 02:03.00 really is supposed to be a delay of 4
         beats." (MG)
         Because of the delay Martin mentioned at 2:03, it led a lot of people
         to believe later parts of the tune went out of synch and it was
         bugged. However, this has been confirmed as intentional. This version
         was known to have been used in Hyper Sports and Transformers.

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Ocean_Loader_2.sid
COMMENT: "'version 2' was a reworking of that tune that I did in late 1985 for
         Comic Bakery. There was actually supposed to be separate loading music
         for every game - that was my plan.  However, I was running out of time
         on projects and in the case of C.B. I simply reworked an older piece.
         After that I _really_ didn't have time to mess with it, and it stuck
         in universal use. Rambo was the only one that got its own loading
         music as part of this plan." (MG)
         This version was in use for many Ocean/Imagine games from late 1985 to
         mid 1987.

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Parallax.sid
COMMENT: Before starting on this game Galway bought Rendez-Vous (by Jean Michel
         Jarre). He listened to it daily. His CD player broke 2 weeks later and
         didn't get repaired for 2 months, during which time Martin worked on
         Parallax, without realizing that Rendez-Vous was unconsciously
         creeping into the music. He realized it only after he played the album
         again after the game was already shipped.
         "[Parallax] was 11 minutes long, certainly my longest at the time. I
         took my development gear home to work on it for a week or two. I just
         said to myself 'OK, it's going to be this mega-tune, so the intro has
         to be mega'. The intro took up two-thirds of the tune! I actually got
         bored with it, and stuck that silly melody on the end which doesn't
         really match. Going back I would have made it less melodic. I wanted
         to reflect the gigantic visual proportions represented by the parallax
         effect in the game so that's why it has an 'epic' feel."(MG)
(#1)
  TITLE: Rendez-Vous [from Rendez-Vous]
 ARTIST: Jean Michel Jarre

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Ping_Pong.sid
COMMENT: "Can't quite remember what happened with 'Ping Pong'. I seem to
         remember not having very much time to work on it. I do recall working
         late on it after everyone else had left, because perhaps I was going
         on holiday the next day or something. (Was it around September-1987?)
         The arcade game didn't have any music on the 'press start' screen, so
         it would have been a natural for an original tune. Maybe everyone
         regarded it as a 'baby game' which didn't merit much attention. CAN'T
         QUITE REMEMBER, sorry!" (MG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Rambo_First_Blood_Part_II.sid
(#1)
COMMENT: The Morse-code heard in voice 1 at the start of the tune spells out
         the names of the games' creators. The decoded Morse-code is below.
         The (*) denotes where the tone of the Morse-code drops. The spelling
         is slightly incorrect, letter 'i' always translates as an 'e'.
         "I wrote that morse code program myself. Nobody touched it but me. It
         was written to handle any text. And I spelt the text right! So - if
         you're right - the problem must have been the software. I'm assuming
         my morsecode book was right of course ;)" (MG)
         -...|.|.-..|.-..|-...|.-|.-.|-.|.-|
         B    E  L    L    B    A  R  N  A              (Bill Barna)
         -..|.-|...-|.|-..|-.-.|---|.-..|.-..|.|.|.-.|
         D   A  V    E D   C    O   L    L    E E R     (David Collier)
         --|.-|.-.|-|.|-.|--.|(*).-|.-..|.--|.-|-.--|
         M  A  R   T E N  G      A  L    W   A  Y       (Martin Galway)
         -|---|-.|-.--|.--.|---|--|..-.|.-.|.|-|
         T O   N  Y    P    O   M  F    R   E T         (Tony Pomfret)
         ..(*).|-|.|...-|.|.--|.-|....|.|-..
         S      T E V    E W   A  H    E D              (Steve Wahid)
(#2)
  TITLE: Stories [from the movie Rambo: First Blood Part II] (2:56-3:06)
 ARTIST: Jerry Goldsmith
(#3)
COMMENT: This is used throughout the moviescore in different places.
         Some parts start with it, some have it in the middle. It's a vital
         ingredient in the whole score.

  TITLE: Ride of the Valkyries

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Rastan.sid
COMMENT: Covers arcade version.
         "The most difficult adaption of a piece of music from a game was the
         Rastan Saga music, that took a while to get all fitted into three
         channels."
         "[...] it was really hard to fit all that stuff on the C64,
         particularly since the dynamic range of arcade game music was starting
         to rise at last, something which the C64 doesn't have much of. (I
         always had that problem with movie conversions of course.)"(MG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Rolands_Ratrace.sid
COMMENT: "Once I had finished on 'Roland's Rat Race', which took a month,
         [Ocean] agreed to suspend my tasks as a programmer and my employment
         as game sound guy began." (MG)
         "[...] the sounds are a bit poor. I didn't develop pulse-width
         modulation until the next project, which at the time was called
         'Cyclone'. It later came out as 'Helicopter Jagd'. On 'Roland's Rat
         Race' I guess you could say I was still mastering the C64. It was
         January/February 1985, my first project on staff at Ocean (I had done
         quite a few before that as a freelancer but they weren't comfortable
         employing someone SOLELY TO DO MUSIC... those were the days!)." (MG)
(#1)
  TITLE: No 1 Ratfan [from The Cassette of the Album] (0:23)
 ARTIST: Pete Hammond, Roddy Matthews and David Claridge (Roland Rat),
         performed by Roland Rat Superstar
(#3)
COMMENT: Same as /MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Hyper_Sports.sid, Tune #25.
(#4)
  TITLE: Bonus Stage [from the arcade game Super Locomotive]
 ARTIST: <?>

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Short_Circuit.sid
COMMENT: "I believe it to be my most elaborate, complete and successful
         conversion of a 'digital audio sourced' tune. ZZAP! 64 only gave the
         music 79%, my worst score since 'Roland's Rat Race', so you can
         imagine my disappointment. One of the other tunes was easy, that's the
         simple ballad melody 'come and follow me', which I was able to arrange
         quite successfully. The other one was a nightmare since it's the tune
         right from the beginning of the movie with all the robotic short notes
         & arpeggios. The tune just built up so massive that the poor C64 was
         short of notes by about 30 seconds into it, so I had to fudge the end
         a bit and make it repeat, basically." (MG)
(#1)
  TITLE: Who's Johnny? [from the movie Short Circuit]
 ARTIST: El DeBarge
COMMENT: "I also had to do 'Who's Johnny?' by El DeBarge for the 'Short
         Circuit' game, that took 4 weeks to program in with all those slides
         and copies of what the record does, I regarded that as quite an
         achievement since it was kind of a neat tune." (MG)
(#4)
  TITLE: Main Title [from the movie Short Circuit]
 ARTIST: David Shire
COMMENT: This music is played when Johnny 5 comes alive!
(#5)
  TITLE: Come and Follow Me [from the movie Short Circuit]
 ARTIST: David Shire, Will Jennings & Max Carl
COMMENT: This is the song played under the credits at the end of the movie. It
         is also the theme song of "Number Five".

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Slap_Fight.sid
COMMENT: Covers arcade version except for tune #1.
         "I didn't have much memory space, I believe around 5 or 6K, so I was
         delighted to copy the arcade game exactly, which had very simple
         sound! That was my most accurate conversion." (MG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Street_Hawk.sid
COMMENT: "The game was re-assigned in early 1986 to Comic Bakery's programmer
         Colin Gresty and artist Steve Wahid, and they enthusiastically got
         to work on it, coming up with an all-new approach with nicer
         graphics - more like the early Grand Theft Auto games (top-down viewed
         from a chase camera).  However it was very slow going for those guys
         and while the art/design was done by mid-1987, Colin was still
         finishing the programming towards the end of that year, say, about
         September.  Ocean, who'd been advertising the game in magazines for
         months, were very annoyed by this delay and were not going to make
         their intended profit. (Perhaps their option window to publish the
         game was expiring too, who knows?) So they cancelled the project when
         it was at the 99%-complete stage and fired Colin." (MG)
         The tune names shown are what Galway called them in his source code.
(#1)
  TITLE: Le Parc (Theme to Street Hawk) [from Le Parc]
 ARTIST: Tangerine Dream
COMMENT: This is a re-interpreted cover by Galway.
         "When I did the 2nd pass at [Street Hawk], I simply bookended the old
         [prototype] version with new stuff, using all my latest techniques.
         If I remember correctly this was the first complete tune I did with a
         proper filter control - perhaps a short time before Wizball.  I also
         incorporated that weird sound from the Parallax walking around
         subtune, where two waveform bits are set simultaneously.  So... you'll
         hear a bunch of fat, juicy filtered bass w/ cool textures, a thinner
         middle bit, then more phat stuff on the end." (MG)
(#2)
   NAME: EnterName
COMMENT: The High-score entry music. A fusion of Galway trademarks: the
         instruments from Parallax Walkabout with the fugue style from Miami
         Vice in-game.
(#3)
   NAME: yieAr
COMMENT: Excerpt from Yie-Ar Kung Fu title music.
(#4)
   NAME: GreenBer
COMMENT: Excerpt from Green Beret title music.
(#5)
   NAME: Parallax
COMMENT: Excerpt from Parallax title music.
(#6)
   NAME: MiamiVic
COMMENT: Excerpt from Miami Vice in-game.
(#7)
   NAME: Rambo
COMMENT: Excerpt from Rambo in-game.
(#8)
   NAME: SpaceInv
COMMENT: Mimicks sound effects from a Space Invaders-type game.
(#9)
   NAME: Hyperthrust
COMMENT: Street Hawk's Hyperthrust kicking in.
(#10)
   NAME: Workshop
COMMENT: Background hum. The tune excerpts (tunes 3-7) go to this subtune
         when they finish.
(#11)
   NAME: InterLevel
(#12)
   NAME: OverSucc
COMMENT: Mission over sound when the mission has been successful.
(#13)
   NAME: OverUnsucc
COMMENT: Mission over sound when the mission was unsuccessful.
(#14)
   NAME: Repairs
(#15)
   NAME: Bullet
(#16)
   NAME: Bike
(#17)
   NAME: Vehicle
(#18)
   NAME: Attention
(#19)
   NAME: Laser
(#20)
   NAME: Refuelling
(#21)
   NAME: Skidding
(#22)
   NAME: WarningLight
(#23)
   NAME: SIbackground
(#24)
   NAME: SIbullet
(#25)
   NAME: SIexploding
(#26)
   NAME: ScrollingMC

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Street_Hawk_Prototype.sid
COMMENT: "Of course I have recollections... where do I begin... are you
         sitting comfortably?  The fact that there are two versions of
         Streethawk music is part of the whole mystery of Streethawk, really.
         It started in 1985 and was programmed by Mike Webb, who'd just come
         off Amstrad Kong Strikes Back. Lateral thinker that he is, he had a
         rather unique design going (a sideways scrolling platform-jumping
         design which is probably now lost forever), and I think he went on
         holiday for a week or two, and when he came back they decided to have
         him do another project - or, he left to join forces with Richard Kay
         at Software Creations. (He definitely did the latter, but I can't
         remember the timeline exactly.)" (MG)
(#1)
  TITLE: Le Parc (Theme to Street Hawk) [from Le Parc]
 ARTIST: Tangerine Dream
COMMENT: This is a re-interpreted cover by Galway. "I had done music for Mike
         Webb's version of the game, simply taking a stab at the title screen
         music without doing anything else.  I did it some time in the summer
         of 1985, so it sonically resembles Cyclone/Helicopter Jagd and
         Neverending Story.  There was no filter technology in my driver. All
         that Ocean had as reference for the show was an NTSC tape of the pilot
         episode of the series, which we were able to play on our futuristic,
         highly-technical NTSC-playback VCR/TV. By listening to the opening &
         closing credits, I put the tune in by ear." (MG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Swag.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: If I Were a Rich Man [from the musical "Fiddler on the Roof"]
 ARTIST: Jerry Bock (music), Sheldon Harnick (lyrics)

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Terra_Cresta.sid
COMMENT: "I tried to create this feeling of a massive behemoth robot monster on
         its way to destroy you. Thus the marching beat and the minor chords
         and stark tones. I had to stick in the inevitable jamming solo towards
         the end of course. I was starting to face the glass ceiling imposed by
         the filter on the C64. While my particular SID sounded great, others
         were not like it at all and the solos were almost inaudible! At the
         other extreme the new C64C's were coming out and this filter
         unreliability had been fixed as part of a silicon revision. BUT the
         filters were way too open all the time and you could hardly hear any
         filtering! This caused the filtered note to come out a lot louder than
         it should have and 'stick out' rather unattractively. So I developed a
         'filter adjustment' parameter for my music program which would allow
         the customer to control this filter unreliability and get their
         particular machine to sound cool. But David Collier never put it in
         the options screen. (DOH!) There's always something wrong, eh?" (MG)
(#2)
  TITLE: Theme of Terra Cresta [from the arcade game] (0:05)
 ARTIST: Kenji Yoshida
(#3)
  TITLE: Theme of Terra Cresta [from the arcade game] (0:03)
 ARTIST: Kenji Yoshida
(#4)
  TITLE: Theme of Terra Cresta [from the arcade game] (0:03)
 ARTIST: Kenji Yoshida
(#5)
  TITLE: Theme of Terra Cresta [from the arcade game] (0:03)
 ARTIST: Kenji Yoshida
(#8)
  TITLE: Theme of Terra Cresta [from the arcade game]
 ARTIST: Kenji Yoshida

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Times_of_Lore.sid
COMMENT: "I remember I squeezed the code & data for 25 sound-effects into 923
         bytes - not bad, eh?" (MG)
(#1)
COMMENT: "The most complex original tune I did was the 'Times Of Lore' title
         tune, it took 20 days just to do the guitar solos! It has a random
         number generator which selects different guitar solos, but I didn't
         realise that people wouldn't leave it looping for its 11-minute
         duration so the work all got sort of wasted." (MG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Wizball.sid
(#2)
COMMENT: The opening bars of this tune are sampled by the group Console on
         their song "14 Zero Zero".
(#4)
COMMENT: "I was working at the Sensible Software office at the time of the
         major music creation, but the title screen music never got finished.
         When I returned to Ocean I got on with some other things, all the time
         worrying about this unfinished tune. Finally I slapped something on
         the end of it. I knew I could never top the first part, that's what
         the problem was. In my mind the second part of the tune is pretty lame
         compared with the first part. But for some people it represents the
         mysterious, magical, unconventional aspect of 'Wizball' so it fits in
         some ways. But you can tell it's not really like the other music in
         the game, which was primarily developed when I was with the Sensi
         boys, basking in that Sensi VIBE." (MG)
         "I really worked on the sound design of the voices a lot. The music
         seems to "flow" and "breathe" unlike anything before it." (MG)
(#5)
COMMENT: "Tune #5, the bonus screen tune, consists of several short riffs, and
         John Hare came up with the most musical ones on his bass guitar. I
         remember he would come up with the riffs, playing them over and over
         at full volume on his band's P.A. in their rented terraced house in
         Southend (not caring about what the neighbours thought!!!) - and while
         they went out to get me a "blow-out" burger at 3am, I would be
         transcribing it and enhancing it (a little)." (MG)
(#7)
COMMENT: "I composed the high-score music at Ocean after returning from
         Southend. Played it on the synth keyboard there. It's one of the few
         compositions of mine that I can actually play a decent rendition of on
         the piano." (MG)
(#8)
COMMENT: "Chris Yates wrote the game over riff on his electric guitar. They
         were pretty impressed by the translation when they came back with my
         blow-out." (MG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Yie_Ar_Kung_Fu.sid
COMMENT: All except tune #19 are covers of the arcade version by Miki Higashino.

  TITLE: Next Opponent [from the arcade game Yie Ar Kung Fu]
 ARTIST: Miki Higashino

  TITLE: Low on Energy [from the arcade game Yie Ar Kung Fu]

(#14)
  TITLE: Opponent Defeated [from the arcade game Yie Ar Kung Fu]
 ARTIST: Miki Higashino
(#15)
  TITLE: Lose a Life [from the arcade game Yie Ar Kung Fu]
 ARTIST: Miki Higashino
(#16)
  TITLE: Game Over [from the arcade game Yie Ar Kung Fu]
 ARTIST: Miki Higashino
(#17)
  TITLE: High Score [from the arcade game Yie Ar Kung Fu]
 ARTIST: Miki Higashino
(#18)
  TITLE: Masterhand History [from the arcade game Yie Ar Kung Fu]
 ARTIST: Miki Higashino
(#19)
  TITLE: Magnetic Fields, Part 4 [from Magnetic Fields]
 ARTIST: Jean Michel Jarre

/MUSICIANS/G/Galway_Martin/Yie_Ar_Kung_Fu_II.sid
COMMENT: "I just tried to come up with a crazy way of settling on a beginning
         note (my favourite beginning note of course, G - almost everything I
         do is in G). So I plugged in this echoing waveform thing and let it
         rip. The tune isn't particularly Chinese sounding, but I was working
         on producing that 'perfect melody', the one you'd be humming all day,
         you know. That was a phase I went through. [...] The sound I was
         converting from was itself a conversion of the arcade cabinet, which I
         have NEVER SEEN. It sounded like it was a lame conversion too, so I
         easily did a better sounding version. (The MSX's music only used two
         notes at once, for example.)" (MG)
(#5)
  TITLE: Firecracker [from Yellow Magic Orchestra]
 ARTIST: Yellow Magic Orchestra (YMO)

### /MUSICIANS/G/Gehrmann_Holger #############################################

/MUSICIANS/G/Gehrmann_Holger/
COMMENT: Holger Gehrmann's own comments are indicated by (HG).
         All tunes are confirmed by Holger Gehrmann to be his.
         Sadly, Holger Gehrmann passed away on February 11, 2008.

/MUSICIANS/G/Gehrmann_Holger/Action_on_Protection.sid
COMMENT: "My first game with scrolling. The songs are conversions of classic
         themes from 'Johann Sebastian Bach'." (HG)
(#1)
  TITLE: Badinerie [from Orchestral Suite No. 2 in B minor (BWV 1067)]
 ARTIST: Johann Sebastian Bach
(#2)
  TITLE: Menuet [from Orchestral Suite No. 2 in B minor (BWV 1067)]
 ARTIST: Johann Sebastian Bach

/MUSICIANS/G/Gehrmann_Holger/Galactic_Meteors.sid
COMMENT: "One of the first machine language based songs I made on the C-64.
         'Soundcontrol' didn't have any fancy features at this time, so the
         songs aren't the greatest. Btw, I thought this game had never been
         released (since I never got any royalties)." (HG)
(#1)
  TITLE: Making Your Mind Up
 ARTIST: Bucks Fizz

/MUSICIANS/G/Gehrmann_Holger/Graffiti_Man.sid
COMMENT: "I didn't like the game, so this song for Rainbow Arts isn't my best
         one..." (HG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Gehrmann_Holger/Hollywood_Poker.sid
COMMENT: "I think this was the first song with the enhanced version of
         'Soundcontrol'. Now it was a sound programming language (SOPROL) where
         you could type in your songs like a basic program (with labels, sound
         commands and so on), and a compiler converted it to machine language.
         Unfortunately the compiled songs were running VERY slow because of the
         structure of the SOPROL language." (HG)
         Holger Gehrmann also did the music for the Amiga version of the game
         which shares the same melody.

/MUSICIANS/G/Gehrmann_Holger/Input_64_Issue_03_85.sid
COMMENT: "For about 6 months I worked at Heise Verlag, and they had a radio
         commercial and wanted it to be converted to the C-64.
         I didn't have an assembler at that time, so I did it with a machine
         language monitor (same as with Galactic Meteors and AOP)." (HG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Gehrmann_Holger/North-Sea_Inferno.sid
COMMENT: "Magic Bytes asked me if I could help them with the game because the
         programmers left the company and went back to Denmark. I finished the
         Atari ST and Amiga version and did the C64 soundtrack. Btw, the
         programmers from Denmark released the game too, it was called 'Persian
         Gulf Inferno'. Magic Bytes sued them for doing this." (HG)
         "In the game credits there might be an 'alias name' (since I wasn't
         allowed to work for other companies at that time :-)" (HG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Gehrmann_Holger/Oil_Imperium.sid
COMMENT: "Karsten Obarski did some great songs for Oil Imperium Amiga, and it
         was my job to convert them to the C64 and IBM PC. My favorite is song
         #3 (Action Sequence 1 'oilfield burning')." (HG)
(#2)
  TITLE: Oil Imperium, Title Tune [from the Amiga game]
 ARTIST: Karsten Obarski
(#3)
  TITLE: Oil Imperium, Oilfield Burning [from the Amiga game]
 ARTIST: Karsten Obarski
(#4)
  TITLE: Oil Imperium, Drilling Sequence [from the Amiga game]
 ARTIST: Karsten Obarski
(#5)
  TITLE: Oil Imperium, Pipeline Building [from the Amiga game]
 ARTIST: Karsten Obarski

/MUSICIANS/G/Gehrmann_Holger/Operation_Hongkong.sid
COMMENT: See /MUSICIANS/G/Gehrmann_Holger/Top_Secret.sid

/MUSICIANS/G/Gehrmann_Holger/Top_Secret.sid
COMMENT: "[This and Operation Hongkong are] two adventure games I made. They
         were coded in a special 'adventure programming language' so I was able
         to convert them for the Atari ST within 2 days (without sound though).
         The Operation Hongkong song was done with a newer version of
         Soundcontrol." (HG)

### /MUSICIANS/G/Geijer_Leif #################################################

/MUSICIANS/G/Geijer_Leif/
COMMENT: "Most of my music are some kind of conversions, I want to create but
         I am not creative enough. Sadly, that seems to be more and more common
         these days.". Comments by Leif are marked (LG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Geijer_Leif/Megaman_1_Dr_Wily_stage_1.sid
  TITLE: Dr. Wily stage 1 [from the NES game Mega Man]
 ARTIST: Manami Matsumae (Chanchacorin), Yoshihiro Sakaguchi (Yuukichan's Papa)
COMMENT: "If Mega Man was ever made for the C64, the music could have been
         like this. It's a shame it wasn't. :)" (LG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Geijer_Leif/Old_Cracktro_Tune.sid
  TITLE: Melodee1 [from the Amiga MOD module]
 ARTIST: Heiko Klueh (Mel o'dee)
COMMENT: "I heard this piece in an old Amiga cracktro, therefore I picked
         this songname. I think it was composed by Mel o'dee, but don't quote
         me on that though. :)" (comment by Leif Geijer-Olsson)

/MUSICIANS/G/Geijer_Leif/Tecmo_World_Wrestling.sid
  TITLE: Akira Dragon [from the NES game Tecmo World Wrestling]
 ARTIST: Keiji Yamagishi, Mayuko Okamura, Hiroshi Miyazaki, Mitsuhito Tanaka
COMMENT: "Another tune from another NES 8-bit game. Didn't like the game, but I
         found this tune extremely catchy. I tried to keep the instruments as
         close as I could to the original, therefore they may sound a little
         bit sleepy." (LG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Geijer_Leif/Tecmo_World_Wrestling_madsync.sid
  TITLE: Akira Dragon [from the NES game Tecmo World Wrestling]
 ARTIST: Keiji Yamagishi, Mayuko Okamura, Hiroshi Miyazaki, Mitsuhito Tanaka
COMMENT: "The same melody as Tecmo_World_Wrestling.sid, but with a bit of
         synchronization added as a little experiment. I think it turned out
         pretty cool, and it sounds like nothing else!" (LG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Geijer_Leif/Tension.sid
  TITLE: Tension [from the game YS]
 ARTIST: Yuzo Koshiro
COMMENT: "The original is a chiptune I found in the '.m' format, which is
         compiled MML code (Music Markup Language). It was, and still is, a
         very popular way to compose computer music in Japan. The tunes are
         written in a text editor and then compiled and maybe processed
         using one or several utilities. Anyway, I thought it was cool and
         decided to make my own version of it." (LG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Gilmore_Adam/Afterburner.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: After Burner [from the arcade game After Burner II]
 ARTIST: Hiroshi Miyauchi (Hiro/SEGA Sound Team)
(#2)

(#1)

(#3)
  TITLE: Batman Theme [from the TV series]
 ARTIST: Neal Hefti

         footage to show me - big joke hahaha." (FG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Fred/Break_Thru.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: Main Theme [from the arcade game Break Thru]
 ARTIST: <?>
COMMENT: Not a cover, but definitely inspired.

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Fred/Dantes_Inferno.sid
COMMENT: "Dante's Inferno was a challenge. I only had 3K of memory and no
         interrupt time to use. I listened to Chopin's 'Dante' music but it was
         awful chromatic crap, so I used Bach, and played some tunes forward
         and again backwards to save memory." (FG)
(#3)
  TITLE: Antioch (Joy to the World)
 ARTIST: Isaac Watts (lyrics), Lowell Mason (music)
COMMENT: Mason borrowed two phrases from Händel's Messiah, "Lift Up Your
         Heads," and "Comfort Ye", when writing this melody.
(#4)
  TITLE: Toccata [from Toccata and Fugue in D Minor (BWV 565)]
 ARTIST: Johann Sebastian Bach
(#5)
  TITLE: <?>
 ARTIST: Johann Sebastian Bach
(#7)
  TITLE: <?>
 ARTIST: Johann Sebastian Bach
COMMENT: Same as #5!
(#12)
  TITLE: Dragnet Theme [from the television series]
 ARTIST: Miklós Rózsa & Walter Schumann

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Fred/Enigma_Force.sid
COMMENT: "I blindly played some chords on the keyboard, and thought 'that
         sounds kewl'". (FG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Fred/Fox_Fights_Back.sid
COMMENT: "Someone described it as pop goes the classics!" (FG)
(#1)
COMMENT: The sound effects are supposed to be the nagging wife. I've had lots
         of experience of that hehe...I love her really. :o) " (FG)
(#3)
  TITLE: March of the Toreadors [from opera Carmen] (0:00-0:40)
 ARTIST: Georges Bizet
  TITLE: Symphony No. 40, First Movement (0:56)
 ARTIST: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
  TITLE: Six Variations on an Original Theme in D major, Op.76 (1:11)
 ARTIST: Ludwig van Beethoven
COMMENT: Beethoven later used the theme in "Marcia alla turca", a section of
         the incidental music "Die Ruinen von Athen", Op.113.
  TITLE: Hungarian Dance No. 5 in F# minor: Allegro - Vivace (1:27-1:53)
 ARTIST: Johannes Brahms

(#2)

(#3)
  TITLE: God Save the King/Queen (The National Anthem of the U.K.)
 ARTIST: Traditional
COMMENT: This anthem is traditional and possibly one of the most known national
         anthems in the world. Each verse was written at a different time,
         ranging from the 1740s to the present day.

(#2)
  TITLE: Something Doing
 ARTIST: Scott Joplin & Scott Hayden
COMMENT: "I knew it was Scott Joplin, as soon as I heard it. I checked the key,
         so I went to the library, borrowed a book of Joplin stuff, looked at
         all the tunes in F major, and I found it. Ventura - music
         detective!!!" (FG)

### /MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/ ##################################################

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/
COMMENT: Matt Gray's own comments are denoted (MDG).

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/720_Degrees.sid
(#1)
  TITLE: <?> [from the arcade game 720 Degrees]
 ARTIST: Hal Canon & Earl Vickers

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Always_on_My_Mind.sid
  TITLE: Always On My Mind
 ARTIST: Johnny Christopher, Mark James & James Thompson
COMMENT: Has been performed by Elvis Presley, Willie Nelson and the Pet Shop
         Boys.

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Autumn_Breeze.sid
  TITLE: Fishing Junks at Sunset [from Concerts in China]
 ARTIST: Jean Michel Jarre
COMMENT: The melody is covered here, the rest is somewhat different.
         Used in the game preview "Omega Ceti", (C) 1987 Ian Moran.

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Crazy_Comets_Special_Re-Mix.sid
  TITLE: Crazy Comets, Tune #1
 ARTIST: Rob Hubbard

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Deliverance.sid
COMMENT: This is the sequel to Stormlord. Apparently, there was some sort of
         competition among the several music composers to have their music in
         this game. Other versions can be found in the following directories:
         Bjerregaard_Johannes, Laxity, and Link.
         "In 1990, I produced Deliverance: Stormlord II, my last ever SID track.
         Ironically, it was for Hewson Consultants, who folded soon after. It
         was time for a change, and by then I was starting to release dance
         music for club play. It's an alright piece of work, though I think the
         sounds were probably better than some of the tunes. I've just reworked
         it for a Kickstarter project and it sounds so much better now." (MDG)
(#3)
  TITLE: In the Hall of the Mountain King [from Peer Gynt] (2:33-2:58)
 ARTIST: Edvard Grieg

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Dominator.sid
COMMENT: "By the time I did Dominator for System 3, a dance-track influence was
         increasingly creeping into my tracks." (MDG)
(#4)
COMMENT: While this tune goes out of sync in the original game, this sid file
         has been fixed and no longer exhibit this behaviour.

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Driller.sid
COMMENT: "Driller, which I did for Incentive Software, was another big turning
         point for me. They wanted something long and epic, not short and
         repetitive. Concept-wise, it was the perfect game for me. It was
         exactly the sort of thing I had been waiting to get my teeth into
         musically. It took four weeks to complete, including an almost
         two-week pause in the middle when the Great Storm of 1987 struck the
         UK, leaving us without electricity or heating for about ten or eleven
         days. I can remember walking down our road one dark evening, wondering
         if I would ever get to use the C64 again, and suddenly noticing all the
         neighbours' lights were finally on again. I went straight in, fired up
         the assembler and carried on composing." (MDG)
(#1)
COMMENT: This is how the game plays the tune, much faster than intended.
         In the game the tune was synced up to the Keyboard interrupts, speeding
         it up and making it two minutes shorter.
  TITLE: Halloween [from the movie] (0:35-2:10)
 ARTIST: John Carpenter
COMMENT: A fast playing cover of the Halloween theme on voice 3.
  TITLE: Phantom of the Opera [from the musical] (6:40-7:40)
 ARTIST: Andrew Lloyd Webber
(#2)
COMMENT: Matt Gray has confirmed this is the way he originally meant the
         tune to be heard.
  TITLE: Halloween [from the movie] (0:41-2:33)
 ARTIST: John Carpenter
COMMENT: A fast playing cover of the Halloween theme on voice 3.
  TITLE: Phantom of the Opera [from the musical] (7:50-9:02)
 ARTIST: Andrew Lloyd Webber

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Election.sid
COMMENT: Same melody as /MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Yogi_Bear.sid

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Equalizer.sid
  TITLE: The Equalizer Busy Equalizing [from the TV series The Equalizer]
 ARTIST: Stewart Copeland

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Fan_Mail.sid
  TITLE: Fan Mail [from Plastic Letters]
 ARTIST: Blondie

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Fruit_Machine_Simulator.sid
COMMENT: "Fruit Machine Simulator was the first track I did for David and
         Richard Darling of Codemasters. I'd met them several times at shows and
         at their offices, and they were always very helpful. They were the ones
         who convinced me to write my own player. Back then, there was little
         chance of doing games music without that skill. It's great to see how
         tremendously well they have done and how they've turned Codemasters
         into a real powerhouse." (MDG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Holiday_Re-Mix.sid
  TITLE: Holiday Morning
 ARTIST: Chris Hülsbeck

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Hunters_Moon.sid
COMMENT: "For Hunter's Moon, which was for Thalamus, I conversed a lot with
         Martin Walker. We often discussed music routines and ideas he had for
         the overall sound of the game. I kind of figured I wouldn't be doing
         the music on his next game, because he was developing his own music
         routine. This was a smooth production, though, and I was pleased with
         the results." (MDG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/KGB_Superspy.sid
COMMENT: "I enjoyed doing KGB Superspy for Codemasters, as I was trying a few
         new tricks, trying to maximise any rhythm elements without using a
         whole channel to do it. The high score theme is actually a straight
         cover of the victory theme from Escape To Victory, which is a football
         version of The Great Escape. It's a film that my mates and I used to
         enjoy as kids because of the many football stars in it, including Pelé
         and Ardiles." (MDG)
(#3)
  TITLE: Let's Go Guys [from the movie Escape to Victory]
 ARTIST: Bill Conti

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Last_Ninja_2.sid
COMMENT: "In 1988, as mentioned, I did The Last Ninja 2 for System 3. I did the
         Central Park tracks first, which was important in order to stamp some
         sort of "sound" on the game. It basically took from mid-January until
         early April to finish. It's about as big a project as you would want to
         undertake, but everything just seemed to work without any real hitches.
         I was given a fairly free hand to produce what I thought would be most
         suitable and luckily, every time I took in new tracks for each level, I
         got the thumbs up. It was a great time for me personally, to suddenly
         be working full time on C64 music. I was almost 18, but I had no real
         worries in the world beyond whether I could afford to buy a better car.
         I think the entire The Last Ninja 2 soundtrack is my proudest
         achievement, especially the Central Park tracks, as they seem to mean
         so much to so many people. The project itself was a pleasure to be part
         of. The whole team involved were probably at the top of their C64 game
         at the time, from John's programming to Hugh's fantastic graphics,
         Tim's storyboarding and of course Mark's overall vision and commitment.
         It's amazing that we're still talking about it nearly 30 years on."
         (MDG)

   NAME: Central Park (loader)
(#2)

   NAME: The Street (loader)

 ARTIST: Jean Michel Jarre

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Maze_Mania.sid
COMMENT: "Maze Mania was the first soundtrack I did for Hewson Consultants. It
         took me about two weeks to complete. I think I did the FX on this, too.
         At the time, this was probably my first freelance track for some 14
         months. It went very smoothly, as I remember." (MDG)
(#3)
  TITLE: Mazemania [from the Amiga game]
 ARTIST: Charles Deenen

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Mean_Streak.sid
COMMENT: Confirmed by Matt Gray to be his. The game did not have music credits.

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Mean_Streak_Loader.sid
COMMENT: Used as tape loading music in game "Mean Streak", (C) 1987 Mirrorsoft.
         See also /MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Mean_Streak.sid

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Motocross.sid
COMMENT: "I'm pretty sure this started out as a track for Turbo Outrun that
         never came out, at least not with my music on it." (MDG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Phantom_Rock.sid
  TITLE: Phantoms of the Asteroid, Tune #1
 ARTIST: Rob Hubbard

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Pogostick_Olympics.sid
COMMENT: "Pogo Stick Olympics was a very last-minute effort for Silverbird, so I
         really can't remember too much about it. I think they had a modified
         demo track." (MDG)

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Professional_BMX_Simulator.sid
COMMENT: "BMX Simulator II, also for Codemasters and also known as Pro BMX, was
         a very quick track to do  it had to be, as it was needed in a hurry.
         It has since taken on a life of its own on the demo scene, though
         apparently, not many people knew it was one of mine." (MDG)
         Later reused in game "Ninja Massacre", (C) 1989 Codemasters.

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Quedex.sid
COMMENT: "Paul Docherty and/or Graham Hunter passed one of my CNet demos on to
         Paul Cooper at Thalamus. They wanted to use it for the loading
         sequence, but it had been written on Soundmonitor. Somehow, they
         managed to get it to play while the game loaded. The in-game tunes
         needed to be written in such a way that if a sound effect played,
         it didn't destroy the music too much. Stavros Fasoulas and Paul Cooper
         drove up to my parents' house where I basically had the top floor of
         a bungalow to myself. Stavros loaded up his game demos and went
         through what was needed. I think it took me about two weeks to do all
         the tunes and FX. Working for such a big name in the industry
         definitely opened up more doors." (MDG)
(#1)
   NAME: Timed Out
(#4)
  TITLE: Monty on the Run, Tune #1
 ARTIST: Rob Hubbard
COMMENT: This covers the part in Hubbard's tune between 2:36 and 2:46.

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Sanxion_Re-load.sid
  TITLE: Thalamusik [from the game Sanxion]
 ARTIST: Rob Hubbard

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Timed_Out.sid
COMMENT: Early version of Quedex loader, released on Compunet before the game.
         See /MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Quedex.sid

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Treasure_Island_Dizzy.sid
COMMENT: "On Treasure Island Dizzy, also for Codemasters, the title theme was my
         version of the original Dizzy music, and the in-game tune had a rhythm
         in 12ths with a heavy swing. I liked the arpeggio chords in it. I also
         like the high score tune, for some reason. I later converted these to
         the NES." (MDG)
(#1)
  TITLE: <?> [from the Spectrum game Treasure Island Dizzy]
 ARTIST: David Whittaker
(#2)
  TITLE: <?> [from the Spectrum game Treasure Island Dizzy]
 ARTIST: David Whittaker
(#3)
  TITLE: <?> [from the Spectrum game Treasure Island Dizzy]
 ARTIST: David Whittaker
(#4)
  TITLE: <?> [from the Spectrum game Treasure Island Dizzy]
 ARTIST: David Whittaker

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Tusker.sid
COMMENT: "Tusker, also for System 3, was an interesting production because I'd
         heard Rob Hubbard create a sound like crickets in the grass or jungle
         on Flash Gordon, so I created a similar sound which was great for the
         general atmosphere on Tusker. The drums and rhythms were also very
         important in this game. There needed to be a tribal sound overall, and
         I think I managed that. I think I spent about four or five weeks on
         this game." (MDG)
(#2)
COMMENT: It may just be a coincidence, but from 2:48 - 3:19 the melody sounds
         identical to a title song in a movie called "Zombie Flesheaters" from
         1979 by Lucio Fulci.

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Vendetta.sid
COMMENT: "In 1989, I did Vendetta for System 3. The first track I did for this
         was a cover of Infected by The The. Paul Docherty introduced me to it
         as a reference, but I took it a little too literally. I had to make a
         lot of use of the filters on this game, to keep the mood. This was
         actually my last game for System 3, sometime around March 1989. I
         think the Maniacs of Noise had rolled into town by then!" (MDG)
         The disk version of the game also uses as loading tune
         /MUSICIANS/H/Hartwig_Stefan/Ultimate_Intro_Studio_tune_06.sid.
(#2)
  TITLE: Si Senor the Hairy Grill [from One Second]
 ARTIST: Yello

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Way_Out_in_Space.sid
  TITLE: Crazy Comets, Tune #2
 ARTIST: Rob Hubbard

/MUSICIANS/G/Gray_Matt/Yogi_Bear.sid
COMMENT: "Yogi Bear, also for Dalali Software, was a very different task as
         compared to Mean Streak and not really my cup of tea, but it was no
         good trying to "cool" it up. It was what it was, but in hindsight,
         I'm amazed I got any other offers after those two efforts!" (MDG)

### /MUSICIANS/G/Greatrix ####################################################

/MUSICIANS/G/Greatrix/Aufidazin_Monty_Cover.sid
  TITLE: Auf Wiedersehen Monty, Tune #1
 ARTIST: Rob Hubbard & Ben Daglish

/MUSICIANS/G/Greatrix/VHD.sid
COMMENT: Due to many complaints about the voting system done at competition
         parties (mainly PC users voting for the C64 competition), Greatrix
         decided to enter the competition with a deliberate pathetic tune. His
         goal was to see if his dismal creation could score higher than some of
         the real competitors proving the system was a complete farce. For this
         particular competition, SymMek98, Greatrix's tune rightfully finished
         last.

         the first seven seconds, and then it plays a random sequence from a
         selection of sixteen each twenty three seconds thereafter.

         the original game behaves this way, too.

  TITLE: Waltzing Matilda
 ARTIST: Marie Cowan (music), A.B. Paterson (lyrics)
COMMENT: Used as the music for Australia.

 ARTIST: Paula von Preradovic (lyrics), Johann Holtzer (music)
(#7)

(#9)
  TITLE: Kong Kristian stod ved højen mast (Danish National Anthem)
 ARTIST: Music from around 1770, lyrics by Johannes Ewald (1779)
(#10)
  TITLE: God Save the King/Queen (The National Anthem of the U.K.)
 ARTIST: Traditional
COMMENT: This anthem is traditional and possibly one of the most known national
         anthems in the world. Each verse was written at a different time,
         ranging from the 1740s to the present day.

 ARTIST: Claude Joseph Rouget de Lisle

 ARTIST: Hiromori Hayashi (music), lyrics come from an ancient poem

 ARTIST: Aleksandr Aleksandrov

         so this country and anthem could not be selected.

/MUSICIANS/G/Groepaz/Nothing_Lasts_Forever.sid
  TITLE: Nichts ist für die Ewigkeit [from Es ist soweit]
 ARTIST: Böhse Onkelz
COMMENT: "This is a cover of the track "Nichts ist für die Ewigkeit" by the
         german rockband "Böhse Onkelz". This "short" version is missing
         some of the original (boring) intro, the second verse(s) and a few
         other bits to make it more interesting for those who don't know the
         original song. I'm not sure if I'll ever polish up the full version, I
         might try another tune instead :)" (Groepaz)

### /MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti ###############################################

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/
COMMENT: All comments by Antti Hannula (AH)
         "I practiced a lot making sids in the late 1980s but released my
         first tunes in 1990.  After Antti Kangas (Scorpion) finished
         his first music routine for Artline Designs (ALD) we started to
         release "quality-sounds".  Before ALD I was the founder member of
         Contex.  All tunes were composed with an assembler." (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/ATA.sid
COMMENT: "Released in 1992, made with ALD-player v3.0 which was developed late
         1990. The routine turned out to be the one I used most, though v3.7
         was even ready at the time.
         The tune itself was the first one I was asked to do for a game. ATA
         was a Tetris-clone done by German Lower Level and I don't recall if I
         got paid for the track, but anyway it was liked by the authors and
         apparently many others.
         This must have been the best track I've done if I don't take count on
         my new tunes. I wasn't anymore much into composing that time, I just
         composed as a time-killer. Also a high score track was included." (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Artlight_Zone.sid
  TITLE: The Twilight Zone [from the TV series]
 ARTIST: Marius Constant
COMMENT: "My first 'good' song with ALD-player v2.1 and one of the few covers I
         ever did. V2.1 didn't have any pulse data for $41 sounds so therefore
         I just used $11 or $21 to have acceptable melody-sounds.
         I was just playing around with the routine and somehow the Zone-theme
         appeared into my mind, but it's only influenced by the theme and the
         rest of the tune was just an effort of imagination.
         Done in January/February 1990." (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/B-Ball.sid
COMMENT: "The B-Ball sounds were ordered in the Autumn 92 just after I had
         released my second music-collection which apparently didn't get spread
         much as I sent it to my old pals, which I even didn't know if they
         were in the scene anymore or not. The B-Ball track however, never got
         released as the game wasn't sold (I guess). I liked this track a lot
         myself and in fact it was the first time I had to do jingles. The
         player I used was v3.6. B-Ball was the last (finished) track I did
         until now in 1999." (AH)
(#1)
   NAME: Main Tune
(#2)
   NAME: Get Ready
(#3)
   NAME: Game Over
(#4)
   NAME: In-game Tune

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Beyond_Grave.sid
COMMENT: "Done in April 1999, yes! The first C64 tune after 1992. This tune
         participated in Proxy 99 party in Finland, even though I wasn't
         present it won the C64 music competition. Some people were really
         amazed to see a track from me for a long long time. I made the basis
         for it with Fasttracker and this is the way I compose the tunes these
         days. It's not a hard job to 'convert' the into assembler if you just
         make the tunes in a 64-style." (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Compact.sid
COMMENT: "Yet another one done in April 1999. I fixed this one just after
         Beyond Grave, but this one I did with the old style - just playing
         around with the routine. Later on I discovered that the arpeggios
         turned out to be much like in Hawkeye by Jeroen Tel. I intended to do
         a slow tune and this is what came out of my head." (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Conflex.sid
COMMENT: "Done in 1990 with v3.0 and was released in my Music Pack #1.
         Nothing special there though I remember I liked it very much back in
         1990. Somehow the "wind-effect" turned out to be in many of my tunes,
         including this one as well. The name comes from Con(tex) and Flex."
         (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Contest_Demo.sid
  TITLE: Contest Demo (part 1)
 ARTIST: Sami Seppä (Rock)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Dance_Attack.sid
  TITLE: Dance Attack [from the XM module]
 ARTIST: Janne Hannula (Jangler)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Deadline.sid
  TITLE: The Deadline
 ARTIST: Sami Seppä (Rock)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Demo_Tune_10.sid
  TITLE: Demo Tune 10
 ARTIST: Sami Seppä (Rock)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Discoland.sid
COMMENT: "I composed this one with Fasttracker II and of course with C64
         sounds. This time transforming the .xm into our C64 music-routine
         turned out to be quite tricky (maybe I just wasn`t in the mood)...
         Anyway, I like the melody and I say that`s the most important element
         in a sid tune." (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Drivers_Dog.sid
COMMENT: "The name comes from Shell`s hot dog which I often eat when coming
         home from my DJ gigs. Quite funky tune and I`m quite pleased with the
         "2nd part" of the song. Uses player v3.7 which was the last ALD-player
         and is the only one which offers you the chance to put bassdrum into
         bass-sound." (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/FanFarewell.sid
COMMENT: "V2.8 production which was a huge step in sounds compared to v2.1 or
         v2.4. I made several tunes with this player back in 1990. The tune
         itself is just a fanfare as you can hear, you could say that this was
         my first high-score track!" (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Feelin_Blue.sid
COMMENT: "Was actually my first released tune and used in the last Contex demo
         called "Handjob Lotion" released May 1990. Used player v2.1 and you
         can hear it from the $21 melody sound. I remember Zardax/Origo played
         this melody in the air pretending there was a keyboard under his
         fingers and asked me what is the song he's playing.. of course I knew
         it!" (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Fields.sid
  TITLE: Sina vain
 ARTIST: Tauski Peltonen.

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Frazze.sid
COMMENT: "Also in "Handjob Lotion" and done with v2.1 as well. This time I used
         $11 melody-sound. Afterwards I've been told this one was at least used
         in a Talent-intro and in Royal Writer. Someone's been liking it." (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Frequency_69.sid
COMMENT: "Done somewhere around late 1991 and released 1992. This was my effort
         to do a techno-track. Uses $15 or $17 ring modulation, $11 bass-drum
         and $11 bass which is played low. I just loved using low frequency
         bass (LFO/LFO) and the tune was inspired by a band called Rhythmatic.
         Scrap/Genesis Project (ex-Contex) reviewed this tune and commented 'Is
         my compu broken?'" (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Funmuzax_1_tune_6.sid
COMMENT:  Deliberately out of tune. "These tunes were done in a joking spirit
          while learning to use FC" (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Ghettoblaster.sid
COMMENT: "Player v2.8. This tune appeared to sound like a general Finnish
         melancholic tune. Nothing special in it." (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Jammin.sid
COMMENT: "This one was meant to be a jamming intro-tune, nothing else. I
         created a "going" bassline and simple chorus into it and later on I
         added a short melody. I like it!" (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Maniac.sid
  TITLE: Maniac [from the movie Flashdance]
 ARTIST: Michael Sembello

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Mello-D_Pop.sid
COMMENT: "I can recall quite clearly that I designed the arpeggios with my
         synthesizer and that was all I needed. I also used to create the
         melodies by playing the bass and chorus from C64 and the melody from
         the synth, it was quite easy. However, I should have done longer
         melodies, too often the melody lasted for 16 beats and then I just
         repeated it." (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Mindblowing.sid
COMMENT: "The intro music for "The Return of A" - my music collection #2.
         The first time I used $11 in arpeggios. I think this tune got its
         right atmosphere right from the beginning. The pulse bassdrum was
         meant to be as a heartbeat, oooh I loved the bass-sound. So simple so
         cool!" (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/My_First_Introtune.sid
COMMENT: "OK, who could have avoided Future Composer? I practiced a lot with it
         and this one was actually made back in 1988, but I never got the
         courage to release it.. I wonder why, after eleven years it actually
         sounds quite nice (done by me when I was 14)." (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Needle.sid
COMMENT: "I don't know what there is, but I like this one though many others
         did not. Perhaps the minimal sounds... It's just so simple!!" (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/No_Worries.sid
  TITLE: Ei mitään hätää
 ARTIST: Samuli Edelman

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Peggy.sid
  TITLE: Peggy
 ARTIST: Jarmo Nikku, performed by Samuli Edelmann
COMMENT: "My first actual cover, done in 1991. This song was chosen the "Song
         of Autumn" in Finnish TV, by the viewers. This was one of my
         favourites on my music-collection #2. Anyway, now I prefer the remix."
         (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Peggy_remix.sid
  TITLE: Peggy
 ARTIST: Jarmo Nikku, performed by Samuli Edelmann
COMMENT: "This version got it going... Well, ain`t that what a remix is
         supposed to do." (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Quite_Acid.sid
COMMENT: "The bassline I'm using in this one was very typical for the early
         acid/house tracks back in 1990, you see I was really into it. Just for
         intros!" (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Reflection.sid
COMMENT: "Done in 1992. This song must have started from the bassline!" (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Russian.sid
  TITLE: Polyushko-polye [from Symphony No. 4 "Poem of the Komsomol Soldier"]
 ARTIST: Lev Knipper
COMMENT: "I was searching for notebooks and then I found this one. There was no
         need to take a closer look, I went to the computer and in a while it
         was ready." (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Superstitious.sid
COMMENT: "The bass and chorus must sound familiar, eh? I think this one is
         boring, well it was my first tune which lasted more than 4 minutes.
         Done in 1990 (v2.8)" (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Swing_it.sid
COMMENT: "This must have been a fast-made track, got the feeling., I don't
         remember how it got spread, but I was surprised to see it in the HVSC.
         Probably done in 1991 for Giants (?)" (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Swing_it_2.sid
COMMENT: "Well, this is the one that actually swings! Done in April 1992 and
         released separately at the same time as music collection #2. This one
         is an exception to my usual formula which was "there must be a
         bassline and drums with melody". (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Tekno_A-Sid.sid
COMMENT: "You could say this one is the sequel to Frequency 69, more low bass
         and a nice rhythm. Done in February 1992 and released separately on
         the same disk as music collection #2. Grooovy!!" (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Theme.sid
COMMENT: "Yet another one of my new tunes done in 1999. This piece participated
         in the Assembly`99 music-compo and gained the 5th place. Done with our
         old player v3.1 done back in 1990 or something. One of my own the
         favourites." (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Top_Gun_Anthem.sid
  TITLE: Top Gun Anthem [from the movie]
 ARTIST: Harold Faltermeyer

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Vertigo.sid
  TITLE: Vertigo
 ARTIST: Sami Seppä (Rock)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Weekend.sid
COMMENT: "My first longer tune done back in 1990 with v2.8. Well, you could say
         that this is a prototype of what my music was back in 1990. Sounded
         too much the same.." (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Wicked_Thing.sid
COMMENT: "Done in 1992. One of the tunes I dislike :-(" (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/Wonderland.sid
  TITLE: Satumaa
 ARTIST: Unto Mononen, performed by Eino Grön
COMMENT: "This is a cover of the most popular Finnish tango ever. I translated
         the arpeggios directly from a notebook (but where is the tango-beat?).
         Still the most played song in Finnish radio and an all time Finnish
         people's favourite!" (AH)

/MUSICIANS/H/Hannula_Antti/You_Deserve_Gold.sid
  TITLE: Sinä ansaitset kultaa
 ARTIST: Jari Sillanpää

/MUSICIANS/H/Hartshorne_Bob/Soundwave_Tubular_Bells.sid
COMMENT: With the aid of the software house CRL and distributor Nu Wave,
         Mike Oldfield released this as an interactive C64 version of
         the album in 1986 accompanied by some simple 2D visual effects.
         The interactivity offered by the album/program was limited to
         controlling the speed and quantity of the visual effects, tuning
         the sound's volume and filtering, and skipping to any part of
         the album. It can be considered the first example of a commercial
         interactive computer demo or "musicdisk".
(#1)
  TITLE: Tubular Bells, Part 1 [from Tubular Bells]
 ARTIST: Mike Oldfield
(#2)
  TITLE: Tubular Bells, Part 1 [from Tubular Bells]
 ARTIST: Mike Oldfield
(#3)
  TITLE: Tubular Bells, Part 1 [from Tubular Bells]
 ARTIST: Mike Oldfield

  TITLE: Tubular Bells, Part 1 [from Tubular Bells]
 ARTIST: Mike Oldfield
(#5)
  TITLE: Tubular Bells, Part 1 [from Tubular Bells]
 ARTIST: Mike Oldfield
(#6)
  TITLE: Tubular Bells, Part 1 [from Tubular Bells]
 ARTIST: Mike Oldfield
(#7)
  TITLE: Tubular Bells, Part 2 [from Tubular Bells]
 ARTIST: Mike Oldfield
(#8)
  TITLE: Tubular Bells, Part 2 [from Tubular Bells]
 ARTIST: Mike Oldfield

  TITLE: Tubular Bells, Part 2 [from Tubular Bells]
 ARTIST: Mike Oldfield

  TITLE: Sailor's Hornpipe
 ARTIST: Traditional

/MUSICIANS/H/Hartwig_Stefan/Ultimate_Intro_Studio_tune_04.sid
  TITLE: Living on Video [from Living on Video] (0:11)
 ARTIST: Trans-X

/MUSICIANS/H/Hartwig_Stefan/Ultimate_Intro_Studio_tune_06.sid
COMMENT: Later used as Side Border Music, (C) 1990 Digital Excess.
         This tune later was also used as loader tune for the System 3 game
         Vendetta, that - just like Myth and Turrican - was timex protected and
         mastered by Markus Wiederstein. In need for a loader tune Wiederstein
         chose tunes the composer gave to Digital Marketing. That's why
         Hartwig's tunes ended up in the games.

/MUSICIANS/H/Hartwig_Stefan/Ultimate_Intro_Studio_tune_07.sid
COMMENT: Later used as the loading theme to the disk version of "Myth",
         (C) 1989 System 3.

/MUSICIANS/H/Hartwig_Stefan/X-ample_Intro_Architect_tune_01.sid
COMMENT: Later used as the disk loading theme to "Turrican", (C) 1990 Rainbow
         Arts. See /MUSICIANS/V/Vaca_Ramiro/Turrican.sid, Tune #1

/MUSICIANS/H/Hartwig_Stefan/X-ample_Intro_Architect_tune_06.sid
COMMENT: Later used as the intro theme to the disk version of "Turrican 2 - The
         Final Fight", (C) 1991 Rainbow Arts. See
         /MUSICIANS/S/Siebold_Markus/Turrican_2-The_Final_Fight.sid, Tune #1.

/MUSICIANS/H/Holt_Hein/Romans_Conquer_the_Discofloor.sid
  TITLE: Athenaios, Paian (DAM 19) & R` h. 6
 ARTIST: Ancient Greek compositions
COMMENT: The first delphic paian of Athenaios was found as inscription on the
         wall of the treasury of Athens and is dated to 128 B.C. R` h. 6 is an
         ancient piece of music found on cuneiform tablets in Ugarit, stemming
         from the 12th century BC. It's the only one out of around 20
         notations that could be reliably reconstructed musically to how it
         might have sounded back then.

/MUSICIANS/H/Holt_Hein/Scott-Land_B-Side.sid
   NAME: Grey Moon Called Walker
COMMENT: A hommage to Martin Walker's style

 ARTIST: Fine Young Cannibals

  TITLE: Flight Of The Starglider [from Its All Downhill From Here]
 ARTIST: Bastian

  TITLE: Stayin' Alive [from the movie Saturday Night Fever]
